summary: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Northern District of Nebraska today announced criminal charges against a Nebraska woman accused of orchestrating a triple-murder.  According to the SEC's complaint, Shanna E. Golyar met David Kroupa through an online dating site. The complaint alleges that from at least late spring or early summer 2012, Goleyar met Farver through a series of online dating websites, including Facebook and YouTube, and that he and Farver engaged in a long-running relationship. The SEC alleges that, from almost the beginning of October 2012 through the end of August 2013, Farver allegedly engaged in an aggressive and aggressive online dating campaign, including sending numerous messages to Farver and telling her that she was going to be a "whore." The complaint further alleges that Golyars used a fake account to convince Farver's mother and stepfather to let her out of the house and into the car. The court ultimately found that the alleged scheme was not a viable one.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York today announced related criminal charges.  The SEC's Office of Investor Education and Advocacy has issued anÂ Investor AlertÂ to encourage investors toÂ check the background of anyone selling or offering them investments in an investment in a real estate development.Â The SEC encourages investors to check the backgrounds of people selling investments in real estate by using theÂ SEC's investorÂ investor.govÂ feature to quickly identify whether they are registered professionals.  Investors can also use the investor.gov website to quickly search for investor information.  For example, the SECÂ recently announced that it has filed a civil injunctive action against Farver, alleging that he violated the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and seeks permanent injunctions, disgorgement of ill-gotten gains with prejudgment interest, and civil money penalties. Â In a separate administrative proceeding, the U. S. Attorney’s Office for New York and the Federal Bureau of Investigation today announced that they have obtained an emergency court order halting the ongoing investigation of Farver.  To learn more about this matter, see Investor.gov/InvestorAdvisers.gov,Â here.
